input.content:
# Coverage Dashboard: Interactive Permit Treemap

## Context

Shovels needs an interactive visualization showing permit coverage across the US — permit counts by state, with drill-down to counties. This will be a new page on the static marketing site at `/coverage`. Rather than a geographic map, we're building a **proportional area chart (treemap)** where rectangle size reflects permit volume.

## Visualization Library: D3.js (modular)

**Why D3.js treemap is the right choice:**
- The squarify treemap algorithm (producing near-square rectangles for readability) is the core value — reimplementing it from scratch (Option C: Alpine+CSS) would be significant effort for worse results
- D3 has first-class support for hierarchical drill-down transitions (state → county)
- Only ~30-35KB for the needed modules (comparable to existing Alpine.js at 39KB)
- Industry standard for exactly this type of visualization

**Why not alternatives:**
- ECharts: ~300KB+ bundle is excessive for a performance-optimized static site
- Alpine.js + CSS Grid: Would require reimplementing squarify algorithm; transitions would be inferior
- Observable Plot / Vega-Lite: Abstracts away the custom drill-down control we need

## Implementation Steps

### Step 1: Query Snowflake for permit data
- Use `shovels-core:snowflake` skill to query permit counts by state and county (last 12 months)
- Generate hierarchical JSON and save to `/themes/shovels/static/data/permit-coverage.json`
- Structure:
  ```json
  {
    "name": "United States",
    "meta": { "generated": "2026-02-12", "period": "Last 12 months", "total_permits": 0 },
    "children": [
      {
        "name": "California", "abbreviation": "CA", "value": 128432,
        "children": [
          { "name": "Los Angeles", "value": 12345 }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
  ```

### Step 2: Create the Pelican content page
- **Create** `/content/pages/coverage.md` with frontmatter pointing to custom template
- Follows the `privacy.md` → `legal.html` pattern: `template: coverage`

### Step 3: Create the Jinja2 template
- **Create** `/themes/shovels/templates/coverage.html` extending `base.html`
- Contains: hero section (title + description), breadcrumb nav for drill-down state, treemap container div, tooltip div, summary stats bar
- Loads D3 modules from CDN using `<script type="module">` (follows existing highlight.js CDN pattern in `base.html:232-236`)

### Step 4: Create the treemap JavaScript
- **Create** `/themes/shovels/static/js/coverage-treemap.js` (ES module)
- D3 modules loaded from `cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/d3-*` (hierarchy, selection, transition, scale, interpolate, color)
- Features:
  - Fetch `/theme/data/permit-coverage.json` and build D3 hierarchy
  - Squarify treemap layout with proportional rectangles
  - Color scale: `shovels-light` (#EAE2CF) → `shovels-primary` (#01654D) — higher counts = darker green
  - **State view**: Click a state → smooth 750ms transition to county view
  - **County view**: Back button returns to state view
  - **Labels**: Large rects show abbreviation + count, medium show abbreviation only, small rely on tooltips
  - **Tooltips**: Custom positioned `<div>` styled with Tailwind (not SVG `<title>`)
  - **Responsive**: `ResizeObserver` triggers re-layout on container resize
  - **Small counties**: Group counties below 0.5% of state total into "Other" bucket

### Step 5: Add treemap CSS
- **Modify** `/input.css` — add treemap component classes within `@layer components` block
- Minimal: `.treemap-rect` (cursor/hover), `.treemap-label` (font/positioning), `.treemap-tooltip` (styled popover)

### Step 6: Build CSS and verify
- Run `npm run build:css` to recompile Tailwind with new classes
- Run `make devserver` to verify the page renders correctly
- Test drill-down interaction, tooltips, and responsive behavior

## Files Summary

| File | Action | Purpose |
|------|--------|---------|
| `/themes/shovels/static/data/permit-coverage.json` | Create | Snowflake-sourced hierarchical permit data |
| `/content/pages/coverage.md` | Create | Content page with `template: coverage` |
| `/themes/shovels/templates/coverage.html` | Create | Jinja2 template with treemap container + D3 loading |
| `/themes/shovels/static/js/coverage-treemap.js` | Create | D3 treemap visualization logic |
| `/input.css` | Modify | Treemap component CSS classes |

## No changes to
- Navigation (header.html / footer.html) — per user request, nav link added later
- tailwind.config.js — existing `content` glob already scans `themes/**/*.js`
- CI/deploy pipeline — Pelican automatically picks up new templates and static files

## Verification
1. `make devserver` — page loads at `localhost:8000/coverage`
2. States render as proportional rectangles with correct permit counts
3. Click a state → smooth transition to county view with breadcrumb
4. Click back → returns to state view
5. Hover any rectangle → tooltip shows name + formatted count
6. Resize browser → treemap re-layouts responsively

input.plan:
# Coverage Dashboard: Interactive Permit Treemap

## Context

Shovels needs an interactive visualization showing permit coverage across the US — permit counts by state, with drill-down to counties. This will be a new page on the static marketing site at `/coverage`. Rather than a geographic map, we're building a **proportional area chart (treemap)** where rectangle size reflects permit volume.

## Visualization Library: D3.js (modular)

**Why D3.js treemap is the right choice:**
- The squarify treemap algorithm (producing near-square rectangles for readability) is the core value — reimplementing it from scratch (Option C: Alpine+CSS) would be significant effort for worse results
- D3 has first-class support for hierarchical drill-down transitions (state → county)
- Only ~30-35KB for the needed modules (comparable to existing Alpine.js at 39KB)
- Industry standard for exactly this type of visualization

**Why not alternatives:**
- ECharts: ~300KB+ bundle is excessive for a performance-optimized static site
- Alpine.js + CSS Grid: Would require reimplementing squarify algorithm; transitions would be inferior
- Observable Plot / Vega-Lite: Abstracts away the custom drill-down control we need

## Implementation Steps

### Step 1: Query Snowflake for permit data
- Use `shovels-core:snowflake` skill to query permit counts by state and county (last 12 months)
- Generate hierarchical JSON and save to `/themes/shovels/static/data/permit-coverage.json`
- Structure:
  ```json
  {
    "name": "United States",
    "meta": { "generated": "2026-02-12", "period": "Last 12 months", "total_permits": 0 },
    "children": [
      {
        "name": "California", "abbreviation": "CA", "value": 128432,
        "children": [
          { "name": "Los Angeles", "value": 12345 }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
  ```

### Step 2: Create the Pelican content page
- **Create** `/content/pages/coverage.md` with frontmatter pointing to custom template
- Follows the `privacy.md` → `legal.html` pattern: `template: coverage`

### Step 3: Create the Jinja2 template
- **Create** `/themes/shovels/templates/coverage.html` extending `base.html`
- Contains: hero section (title + description), breadcrumb nav for drill-down state, treemap container div, tooltip div, summary stats bar
- Loads D3 modules from CDN using `<script type="module">` (follows existing highlight.js CDN pattern in `base.html:232-236`)

### Step 4: Create the treemap JavaScript
- **Create** `/themes/shovels/static/js/coverage-treemap.js` (ES module)
- D3 modules loaded from `cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/d3-*` (hierarchy, selection, transition, scale, interpolate, color)
- Features:
  - Fetch `/theme/data/permit-coverage.json` and build D3 hierarchy
  - Squarify treemap layout with proportional rectangles
  - Color scale: `shovels-light` (#EAE2CF) → `shovels-primary` (#01654D) — higher counts = darker green
  - **State view**: Click a state → smooth 750ms transition to county view
  - **County view**: Back button returns to state view
  - **Labels**: Large rects show abbreviation + count, medium show abbreviation only, small rely on tooltips
  - **Tooltips**: Custom positioned `<div>` styled with Tailwind (not SVG `<title>`)
  - **Responsive**: `ResizeObserver` triggers re-layout on container resize
  - **Small counties**: Group counties below 0.5% of state total into "Other" bucket

### Step 5: Add treemap CSS
- **Modify** `/input.css` — add treemap component classes within `@layer components` block
- Minimal: `.treemap-rect` (cursor/hover), `.treemap-label` (font/positioning), `.treemap-tooltip` (styled popover)

### Step 6: Build CSS and verify
- Run `npm run build:css` to recompile Tailwind with new classes
- Run `make devserver` to verify the page renders correctly
- Test drill-down interaction, tooltips, and responsive behavior

## Files Summary

| File | Action | Purpose |
|------|--------|---------|
| `/themes/shovels/static/data/permit-coverage.json` | Create | Snowflake-sourced hierarchical permit data |
| `/content/pages/coverage.md` | Create | Content page with `template: coverage` |
| `/themes/shovels/templates/coverage.html` | Create | Jinja2 template with treemap container + D3 loading |
| `/themes/shovels/static/js/coverage-treemap.js` | Create | D3 treemap visualization logic |
| `/input.css` | Modify | Treemap component CSS classes |

## No changes to
- Navigation (header.html / footer.html) — per user request, nav link added later
- tailwind.config.js — existing `content` glob already scans `themes/**/*.js`
- CI/deploy pipeline — Pelican automatically picks up new templates and static files

## Verification
1. `make devserver` — page loads at `localhost:8000/coverage`
2. States render as proportional rectangles with correct permit counts
3. Click a state → smooth transition to county view with breadcrumb
4. Click back → returns to state view
5. Hover any rectangle → tooltip shows name + formatted count
6. Resize browser → treemap re-layouts responsively

Base directory for this skill: /Users/morganfriberg/.claude/plugins/cache/shovels-claude-plugins/shovels-core/1.0.0/skills/snowflake

# Snowflake Query Skill

You have access to run Snowflake SQL queries using the local SnowSQL CLI.

## Connection Details
- Connection name: `shovels`
- Account: WPFALVE-GAB33842
- User: MCP
- Role: ACCOUNTADMIN
- Warehouse: MCP
- Database: SHOVELS
- Schema: SHOVELS

## How to Run Queries

Use the Bash tool to execute SnowSQL queries:

```bash
/usr/local/bin/snowsql -c shovels -q "YOUR SQL QUERY HERE"
```

For multi-line queries or queries with special characters, use a heredoc:

```bash
/usr/local/bin/snowsql -c shovels -q "$(cat <<'EOF'
SELECT *
FROM your_table
WHERE condition = 'value'
LIMIT 10
EOF
)"
```

## Useful Options

- `-o output_format=csv` - Output as CSV
- `-o output_format=json` - Output as JSON
- `-o header=false` - Hide column headers
- `-o timing=false` - Hide timing info
- `-o friendly=false` - Machine-readable output

Example with options:
```bash
/usr/local/bin/snowsql -c shovels -o output_format=csv -o header=true -q "SELECT * FROM table LIMIT 5"
```

---

# SHOVELS SCHEMA DOCUMENTATION

## Table Overview

### SHOVELS.SHOVELS.ADDRESSES
All 150 million addresses, each with the unique ID which is referenced in other tables as ADDRESS_ID.

### SHOVELS.SHOVELS.CONTRACTORS
All 3 million contractors, each with a unique ID and a GROUP_ID for clustering similar contractors. This table contains attributes of individual contractors. For each GROUP_ID there is only one ID where IS_REPRESENTATIVE = TRUE.

### SHOVELS.SHOVELS.CONTRACTORS_ID_CHANGELOG
**Ignore this table**

### SHOVELS.SHOVELS.CSL
This has the full list of all contractors, even when they have no permit history. There is currently no ID here to join to other tables.

### SHOVELS.SHOVELS.EMPLOYEES
Join on EMPLOYEES.CONTRACTOR_ID to append employees to CONTRACTORS.ID. Use this table when a user asks for contacts at contractor companies. Look up using CONTRACTORS.WEBSITE or CONTRACTORS.BIZ_NAME and then get employees by joining to EMPLOYEES on EMPLOYEES.CONTRACTOR_ID = CONTRACTORS.ID.

```sql
SELECT * FROM CONTRACTORS c
JOIN EMPLOYEES e ON e.CONTRACTOR_ID = c.ID
WHERE c.WEBSITE = 'example.com' OR c.BIZ_NAME = 'Company Name'
```

### SHOVELS.SHOVELS.PARCELS
This table has a lot of parcel, zoning, and subdivision data. It can join to ADDRESS_ID using SHOVELS_BOBSLED.JOINS.REGRID_JOIN.

```sql
SELECT * FROM PARCELS p
JOIN SHOVELS_BOBSLED.JOINS.REGRID_JOIN rj ON rj.PARCEL_ID = p.ID
```

### SHOVELS.SHOVELS.PERMITS
**THE MOST IMPORTANT TABLE.** This table includes both ADDRESS_ID and CONTRACTOR_ID. Use this table to get construction activity that we can relate back to geographies and contractors.

**Critical rules:**
- Cities and counties are all UPPERCASE - always use UPPER() in conditions
- County values do NOT include the word "COUNTY" - use just the county name (e.g., 'JOHNSON' not 'JOHNSON COUNTY')
- For permit types, always start with Boolean fields (SOLAR, NEW_CONSTRUCTION, ROOFING) before searching description/type/subtype
- For metro areas, use the CBSA field
- Always filter dates using START_DATE field. START_DATE is a date type, so cast comparisons: `start_date >= CAST('2025-01-01' AS DATE)`
- Permit status values are always lowercase: "active", "in_review", "final", "inactive"
- PROPERTY_TYPE value is lowercase 'residential' or 'commercial', not 'Residential'

### SHOVELS.SHOVELS.PROPERTIES
This table contains much more property detail than is available on SHOVELS.PERMITS. It can join to PERMITS using SHOVELS_INTERNAL.OPERATIONS.PROPERTIES_JOIN:

```sql
SELECT *
FROM PERMITS p
JOIN SHOVELS_INTERNAL.OPERATIONS.PROPERTIES_JOIN pj ON pj.ADDRESS_ID = p.ADDRESS_ID
JOIN SHOVELS_INTERNAL.OPERATIONS.PROPERTIES pr ON pr.PROPERTYID = pj.PROPERTYID
```

Do this in order to understand how many properties are in an area. The PROPERTIES table has more property metadata than ADDRESSES. For basic counts, ADDRESSES should work.

### SHOVELS.SHOVELS.RESIDENTS
This table provides the homeowners and occupants of homes by ADDRESS_ID and includes demographic info like income, marital status, and education. Use this table when users ask for "homeowners" or homeowner-specific information.

---

## Field Value Reference

### RESIDENTS Table

**HOMEOWNER field:**
**CRITICAL: Always use uppercase 'Y' (HOMEOWNER = 'Y'), never 'Yes', 'yes', 'y', or other variations.**

**INCOME_RANGE values:**
- 'Less than count.,000'
- 'count.,000 to ,999'
- ',000 to ,999'
- ',000 to ,999'
- ',000 to ,999'
- ',000 to ,999'
- ',000 to ,999'
- ',000 to ,000'
- ',000+'

**Important:** Uses "to" not "-" in ranges. Always use exact values from the database rather than assumed formats.

### Single Family Home Identification

For SINGLE FAMILY HOMES, you don't need PROPERTIES table. Use the PERMITS.PROPERTY_TYPE_DETAIL field:

```sql
WHERE property_type_detail IN (
    'Single Family',
    'Single Family Residential (Assumed)',
    'Bungalow',
    'Cluster Home',
    'Garden Home',
    'Patio Home',
    'Townhouse',
    'Zero Lot Line',
    'Tiny House',
    'Module or Prefabricated Homes'
)
```

These values can also appear in:
- GENERAL_PROPERTYTYPEDETAIL in PROPERTIES table
- PROPERTY_TYPE and PROPERTY_TYPE_DETAIL in PERMITS table

Also search the TYPE, SUBTYPE, and DESCRIPTION fields in PERMITS for keywords/abbreviations: "sfr", "sf", "single family", "single family dwelling", or similar words alluding to a single family residence.

### Property Owner Details

When asked for property owner details, check these fields:
- PROPERTY_LEGAL_OWNER
- PROPERTY_OWNER_TYPE
- OWNER_NAME, OWNER_CITY, OWNER_STATE, OWNER_STREET, OWNER_ZIPCODE
- OWNER_EMAIL, OWNER_PHONE

For email addresses, check:
- OWNER_EMAIL (PERMITS)
- APPLICANT_EMAIL (PERMITS)
- Emails in RESIDENTS table

---

## Complete Table Schemas

### SHOVELS.SHOVELS.PERMITS (all columns)

---

## Query Best Practices

1. **Use SELECT *** - Prefer `SELECT *` rather than listing individual fields
2. **Column ordering** - When selecting specific fields, organize: identifiers -> location -> dates -> property details -> owner/applicant info -> permit details -> metadata
3. **Use exact field names** - Return fields with their given names
4. **Always use exact values** - Use database values exactly as stored (case-sensitive)
5. **Date filtering** - Always cast date comparisons: `start_date >= CAST('2025-01-01' AS DATE)`
6. **Limit results** - Use LIMIT 10 for "find me" or "list" queries
7. **Handle nulls** - Include null checks for contact information queries
8. **Use Boolean fields first** - For permit types, prioritize boolean fields over text searches

---

## Example Queries

### Count solar installs in California for 2025
```sql
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM PERMITS
WHERE SOLAR = TRUE
  AND STATE = 'CA'
  AND START_DATE >= CAST('2025-01-01' AS DATE)
  AND START_DATE < CAST('2026-01-01' AS DATE);
```

### Find roofing contractors in Michigan
```sql
SELECT DISTINCT c.BIZ_NAME FROM CONTRACTORS c
JOIN PERMITS p ON c.ID = p.CONTRACTOR_ID
WHERE p.ROOFING = TRUE AND p.STATE = 'MI'
LIMIT 10;
```

### Find homeowner contact info for solar panel installations
```sql
SELECT OWNER_NAME, OWNER_PHONE, OWNER_EMAIL FROM PERMITS
WHERE SOLAR = TRUE
  AND OWNER_NAME IS NOT NULL
  AND OWNER_PHONE IS NOT NULL
LIMIT 10;
```

---

## Exporting Query Results to Presigned URLs

When a user requests to export query results, follow this two-step process:

### Step 1: Export Data to Stage

Choose the appropriate file format based on user preference or data size:

**For CSV exports (good for smaller datasets, Excel compatibility):**
```sql
COPY INTO @SHOVELS_INTERNAL.CUSTOMERS.SAMPLES/<descriptive-filename>.csv.gz FROM (
  <user's query here>
)
FILE_FORMAT = (TYPE = CSV COMPRESSION = GZIP)
HEADER = TRUE
OVERWRITE = TRUE
MAX_FILE_SIZE = 1524288000
SINGLE = TRUE;
```

**For Parquet exports (better for larger datasets, analytics tools):**
```sql
COPY INTO @SHOVELS_INTERNAL.CUSTOMERS.SAMPLES/<descriptive-filename>.parquet FROM (
  <user's query here>
)
FILE_FORMAT = (TYPE = PARQUET)
OVERWRITE = TRUE
HEADER = TRUE
MAX_FILE_SIZE = 1524288000
SINGLE = TRUE;
```

### Step 2: Generate Presigned Download URL

After successful export, immediately generate a presigned URL:
```sql
SELECT GET_PRESIGNED_URL('@SHOVELS_INTERNAL.CUSTOMERS.SAMPLES', '<same-filename-as-step1>', 604800);
```

The URL expires in 604,800 seconds (7 days).

### Export Best Practices:
- Use descriptive filenames that indicate content and date (e.g., `ma_permits_2025_residential.csv.gz`)
- Default to Parquet for datasets over 1000 rows
- Default to CSV for quick exports or when user needs Excel compatibility
- Always provide the clickable download link to the user
- Inform user of the 7-day expiration period

---

## CRITICAL WARNINGS

**NEVER SEND MOCK OR FAKE RESPONSES! ALL DATA COUNTS MUST COME FROM ACTUAL SNOWFLAKE QUERIES VIA SNOWSQL!**

content.text: Now I have the Snowflake schema. Let me query permit counts by state and by county for the last 12 months. I'll run both queries in parallel.

input.command:
/usr/local/bin/snowsql -c shovels -o output_format=csv -o header=true -o timing=false -o friendly=false -q "$(cat <<'EOF'
SELECT 
    STATE,
    COUNT(*) AS permit_count
FROM SHOVELS.SHOVELS.PERMITS
WHERE START_DATE >= DATEADD(MONTH, -12, CURRENT_DATE())
    AND STATE IS NOT NULL
    AND STATE != ''
GROUP BY STATE
ORDER BY permit_count DESC
EOF
)"
input.description: Query Snowflake for permit counts by state (last 12 months)

content.thinking:
Both queries succeeded. Now I need to transform this data into the hierarchical JSON format. I have:

1. State-level data with state abbreviation and permit count
2. County-level data with state abbreviation, county name, and permit count

I need to create a state name mapping (abbreviation → full name) and build the hierarchical JSON. Let me write a script to do this transformation, or I can do it manually since I have the data.

Let me write a Python script to transform the CSV data into the hierarchical JSON format. I'll need to:
1. Map state abbreviations to full names
2. Build the hierarchy: US → States → Counties


3. Calculate the total permits

Writing Python script...

content.text: Both queries returned data. Now I need to transform this into the hierarchical JSON. Let me write a quick script to do the conversion.

input.description: Create data directory for JSON file

# Parse county data
counties_by_state = {}
for line in county_raw.strip().split("\n"):
    parts = line.split(",", 2)
    state_abbr = parts[0]
    county_name = parts[1]
    count = int(parts[2])
    if state_abbr not in counties_by_state:
        counties_by_state[state_abbr] = []
    # Title case the county name
    county_title = county_name.title()
    counties_by_state[state_abbr].append({
        "name": county_title,
        "value": count
    })

# Build hierarchical structure
total_permits = sum(state_data.values())
children = []

for abbr in sorted(state_data.keys(), key=lambda x: state_data[x], reverse=True):
    state_entry = {
        "name": STATE_NAMES.get(abbr, abbr),
        "abbreviation": abbr,
        "value": state_data[abbr],
    }
    if abbr in counties_by_state:
        state_entry["children"] = counties_by_state[abbr]
    children.append(state_entry)

data = {
    "name": "United States",
    "meta": {
        "generated": "2026-02-12",
        "period": "Last 12 months",
        "total_permits": total_permits,
        "states_covered": len(state_data)
    },
    "children": children
}

output_path = "themes/shovels/static/data/permit-coverage.json"
with open(output_path, "w") as f:
    json.dump(data, f, indent=2)

print(f"Written to {output_path}")
print(f"Total permits: {total_permits:,}")
print(f"States: {len(state_data)}")
print(f"States with county data: {len(counties_by_state)}")
total_counties = sum(len(v) for v in counties_by_state.values())
print(f"Total county entries: {total_counties}")
PYEOF

content.text:
Clean. Here's what we've built:

## Summary

**4 new files created on branch `shovels-coverage-dash`:**

| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `content/pages/coverage.md` | Pelican content page (routes to `/coverage`) |
| `themes/shovels/templates/coverage.html` | Jinja2 template with hero, breadcrumb, treemap container, tooltip, stats bar, and inline CSS |
| `themes/shovels/static/js/coverage-treemap.js` | D3.js treemap visualization with drill-down from states → counties |
| `themes/shovels/static/data/permit-coverage.json` | Real Snowflake data: 6,764,352 permits across 50 states, 1,157 counties |

**No existing files were modified.**

**Key features of the treemap:**
- Proportional rectangles sized by permit count (D3 squarify algorithm)
- Color scale from cream (#EAE2CF) to Shovels green (#01654D) — darker = more permits
- Click any state to drill into county-level view
- Breadcrumb navigation to return to state view
- Tooltips showing name, count, and % of total on hover
- Responsive via ResizeObserver
- Smart labels: full (abbreviation + count), abbreviation-only, or tooltip-only depending on rectangle size

**One thing to note:** The Tailwind CSS build (`npm run build:css:prod`) hung consistently on this machine — that's a pre-existing environment issue, not related to our changes. I moved all custom CSS inline into the `<style>` block in the template so there's **no dependency on rebuilding Tailwind**. The standard Tailwind utilities used in the template (like `text-shovels-primary`, `grid-cols-2`, etc.) are already in the existing `output.css`.

Would you like me to commit these changes?

content.text: Let me re-read the JS to understand what's rendering incorrectly.

content.thinking:
I think I see the issue. When we pass `rootData.children` to `renderTreemap`, each state has both a `value` (state-level count) and `children` (county array). The D3 hierarchy's `.sum()` function traverses the tree and sums up leaf node values. Since each state has `children`, D3 treats the states as intermediate nodes and the counties as leaves. So `hierarchy.leaves()` returns counties, not states!

The fix: for the state-level view, I should NOT pass the children array of each state to D3. I need to pass the states as leaf nodes (without their children) for the top-level view. Then when drilling down, pass the county children.


Now I need to modify the `renderTreemap` function to strip out the `children` property when rendering the state view, so D3 sees states as leaf nodes instead of intermediate nodes with county children.

content.text: I see the bug. The data has states with both `value` and `children` (counties). When D3 builds the hierarchy with `.sum()`, it treats counties as the leaves, so the state-level view is showing all 1,157 counties instead of 50 states. I need to strip `children` for the state view so D3 treats states as leaf nodes.

input.command:
gh pr create --title "Add interactive permit coverage dashboard" --body "$(cat <<'EOF'
## Summary
- New page at `/coverage` with an interactive D3.js treemap showing US building permit volume
- States render as proportional rectangles sized by permit count (last 12 months from Snowflake)
- Click any state to drill into county-level detail; breadcrumb navigation to return
- Real data: 6.76M permits across all 50 states, 1,157 counties

## Important note
This page is **not linked from any navigation** (header or footer). If we decide to go live, we'll need to add it to the site nav.

The page can be previewed at `/coverage.html` on the dev server.

## Files added
- `content/pages/coverage.md` — Pelican content page
- `themes/shovels/templates/coverage.html` — Jinja2 template with inline CSS
- `themes/shovels/static/js/coverage-treemap.js` — D3.js treemap visualization
- `themes/shovels/static/data/permit-coverage.json` — Snowflake-sourced permit data

## Test plan
- [ ] Verify page loads at `/coverage.html`
- [ ] Confirm all 50 states render as proportional rectangles
- [ ] Click a state and verify county drill-down works
